Award.AwardTitle: Optimization in an Uncertain World: A Unified Framework for Optimization Models Involving Adversaries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves the modeling and optimization of decision processes that unfold in stages over time. The explicit incorporation of time stages into models of complex systems is one approach to accounting for an important feature of real-world systems---the presence of adversarial entities whose potentially detrimental actions in the future may disrupt plans being made in the present. Such adversaries' can take the form of either difficult-to-predict random processes (such as the weather or economic conditions) or direct competitors who are actively seeking to disrupt operation of the system. Accounting for such adversaries is challenging from a computational standpoint because it involves implicit knowledge of all the ways in which the future might unfold as a result of a given action. This work is to understand and mitigate the impact of this complexity by developing techniques for compactly representing the effects of uncertainty using sophisticated mathematical techniques, with which, for example, one can intelligently determine a small set of "important'' scenarios whose consideration will still allow for determination of an optimal decision in the present that implicitly takes into account all possible future scenarios.

The general class of optimization problems that will be studied in this project are those in which the variables can be partitioned into subsets whose values must be fixed in stages. The constraints of later stages depend both on the values of variables fixed in earlier stages and on the realized values of certain random variables. A key feature of the general framework is that the variables in each stage may be controlled by different decions-makers with different objective functions. This class includes two important and challenging special cases - multistage stochastic programming with recourse and multilevel programming. The features of these two classes are complimentary and there is much to be gained by development of a unified approach. The overall goal of this research is to develop computational methods for such models, focusing in particular on the case in which there are discrete variables.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we studied the modeling and optimization of decision processes that unfold in stages over time. Such processes arise in many contexts. They are the subject of study in game theory (used to develop economic models and models of competitive markets), and stochastic optimization (used to analyze optimization problems involving inherent uncertainty and risk).

The explicit incorporation of time stages into models of complex systems is one approach to accounting for an important feature of real-world systems---the presence of adversarial entities whose potentially detrimental actions in the future may disrupt plans being made in the present. Such adversaries can take the form of either difficult-to-predict random processes (such as the weather or economic conditions) or cognizant competitors who are actively seeking to disrupt operation of the system or competing in some fashion. Accounting for such adversaries is challenging from a computational standpoint because it involves implicit knowledge of all the ways in which the future might unfold as a result of a given action. This work sought to understand and mitigate the impact of this complexity by developing techniques for compactly representing the effects of uncertainty using sophisticated mathematical algorithms, with which, for example, one can intelligently determine a small set of "important'' scenarios whose consideration will still allow for determination of an optimal decision in the present that implicitly takes into account all possible future scenarios.

One over-arching goal was to develop methodology capable of handling discrete decisions (decisions involving a finite and discrete set of possible options). Typically, this type of decision problem is much more difficult than those involving decisions that occur on a continuum. Another over-arching goals was to show that cognizant adversaries are no different than random phenomena from a theoretical and methodological standpoint. We showed this by creating a unified framework of algorithms that can even handle either style of problem alone or even combinations of the two. 

The intellectual merit of the work was first that it produced a significant corpus of mathematical theory supporting the development of algorithms for solving these types of problems. Built upon this theory, two entirely independent algorithmic frameworks were developed and tested, based on two entirely separate aspects of the developed theory. Both of these frameworks successfully unified the game theoretic and stochastic models, as well as incorporating discrete decision variables. These two algorithmic frameworks were implemented in two software packages, one of which is publicly available as open source software and the other of which will be publicly released as open source software in the near future. These software packages make it possible for entirely unsophisticated users to to formulate and solve instances of these multi-stage optimization problems in a practical fashion. 

Among the broader impacts was that two Ph.D students were supported by the grant and will soon graduate, having produced two dissertations. One of these students has already accepted a job with a major analytics firm.  The methodology and software developed will have a major impact across both industry and academia. Bilevel optimization problems arise in a wide range of important applications areas, including energy, cybersecutiry, machine learning, drug discovery, and many others. The software we developed as part of this grant can be used as a black box by relatively unsophisticated users and is already in broad use in support of other NSF-funded research. 

A wide array of related methodologies evolved from this work that we believe will turn out to be just as important as the core research. As a by-product of our main development, we discovered new methods for solving standard single-stage problems. We also developed methodology for so-called "warm-starting" of computations when a sequence of related problems must be solved. The duality theory that was developed as part of this work has wide application in economic theory and we anticipate using developed notions of price functions to make contributions to such diverse areas as the modeling of energy markets and mechanism design for combinatorial auctions.
